Dr. Maguire acts as a therapist to Will, delving into his deepest fears and worries whilst confronting his own underlying issues in the process.ReviewAt first glance, Good Will Hunting seems like a very generic drama with a quite predictable plot, and it is, there is the unrealistically smart genius to whom we could never relate, who despite being so gifted, needs someone else to help him reach his potential. But what really sets this movie apart, is not the plot or crazy unpredictable characters, but the truly realistic and hard-hitting emotions this movie is able to recreate in the viewer's mind. All the characters undergo their own development arch instead of funneling all their screentime into developing only the protagonist, which makes the movie feel way less constricted. You can see the effect of one person directly and significantly impacting another, just like it would in the real world, and most of the time you can really relate and feel those emotions. But the moments where this movie truly shines are the therapy sessions between Will Hunting and Dr. Sean Maguire. They delve deep into the human psyche and emotions, not being afraid of confronting themselves and the viewer with some harsh truths. You can feel the connection they make during the runtime of the film, and Sean becomes almost a guiding father figure to Will. Of course, the character interactions are not the only strong suit of the film. The acting was truly superb, making you believe everything the characters are saying without a doubt. The synergy between Matt Damon and Robin Williams was immaculate.Conclusion and final thoughtsOverall Good Will Hunting is one incredible movie, achieving such emotional realism that is hard to find these days with all the mainstream blockbusters. It is not afraid to present the rather cruel reality of life, while still showing how to create truly meaningful connections and make you relate to almost all the characters in some way or another. I think this movie is a must-watch for any teenager/young adult.

Review title: A Review: Good Will Hunting by Gus Van Sant
Review_body: 1997s Good Will Hunting by Gus Van Saint is an American drama story that follows a troubled unrecognized genius Will Hunting (Matt Damon) who works as a janitor at MIT. Will is ready to spend his days working a minimal wage job and drinking with his buddies on the weekend until he solves a complex math problem and gets the attention of Prof. Gerald Lambeau who decides to help Will achieve his full potential by solving math problems and getting his life back on track with the help of Dr. Sean Maguire (Robin Williams). Review title: Matt & Ben should write more scripts!
Review_body: I think it is safe to say that anyone who has seen this movie will wonder how two young actors managed to write such a beautiful and realistic story, with characters you can relate to despite the fact that one of them is an overlooked math genius. Add to that creditable performances from everyone involved (esp. Robin Williams in semi-dramatic mode), good directing and wonderful musical contribution from Elliott Smith (who was unfortunate not to win a Grammy for "Miss Misery"), and you have one of the most endearing movies ever. You can tell right away from the first scene that Matt Damon and Ben Affleck are the bestest of friends, and they have several poignant scenes in this movie. Minnie Driver was good as well, and you have to feel for her character. Well, like I said before...those two really should write more scripts, who knows what other stories are stored away in their heads. Watch this movie if you haven't already!

Review title: Never get tired of a good story
Review_body:
I never saw this movie in the cinema. I regret this. Many months later, after the hype subsided, I decided to rent the movie on video. What I watched was a thoroughly entertaining story!It's this kind of story that is simple enough to get enticed straight away and real enough that you don't lose interset half way through.
The real hook for Good Will Hunting, though, is Robin Williams performance. He was good in 'Awakenings' and even better in 'Dead Poets Society', but never better than here as the burnt out councillor who hasn't been challenged in years. He finally meets his match in Will Hunting (Matt Damon).There are many sub-plots in this story, but the ones that will make you sit up and take notice will be the exchanges between Will Hunting and Sean (Robin Williams).There are also many fine supporting performances, some of which have never been bettered in other movies. Stellan Skarsgard is convincing as the pretentious, insecure MIT professor. Ben Affleck also delivers his best performance to date as the ever loyal, Chuckie. Perhaps the only let down performance is by Minnie Driver.Overall, It's the kind of movie you can sit and watch time and time again and never get tired of.I rate it 10 out of 10.

"If you wish others to believe in you, you must first convince them that you believe in them".....a quote which is apt for describing the soul of the movie.... The movie surprises me every time i see it with the sheer depth of the story and strength in each of the characters... it is probably the most defining role of Robin Williams after patch adams and his portrayal of sean is stunning... Matt Damon playing the bad-boy-genius with the fragile mix of lightheartedness and hidden sadness is worth watching and his role is quite beautifully supported by his buddies portrayed by the afflecks and Cole Hauser and also Damon's love interest Skylar (minnie driver)....the directive effort of gus van sant is quite brilliant with the way in which he deals with the characters...expressing their very depths...in most times through long shots with hardly any dialogueI would recommend the movie as a must watch ..... u probably have to buy a copy for posterity...:)

This is one of the best films I've seen to date. I've watched it three times in a row and if I ever picked it off the shelf I'd watch it three times again. Very good with the best speeches ever, The cast is great, very funny -dont listen to stupid people's opions on it, they have no freedom of speach in my view. See it now!

I re-watched this movie the other night. I saw it when it came out and thought it was so-so. A bit predictable really, as people here have pointed out. But I also found it to be entertaining. I like Gus Van Zants films but I was surprised to learn that Matt Damon and Ben Affleck wrote this script. Good job!

this is one of the movies which has inspired me deeply. In some way or the other way this movie depicts the life of people who because of their repression defense mechanism are not able to achieve what they ought to achieve if they haven't repressed their abilities and i was instantly able to attach myself with the character of will hunting as i have myself repressed my abilities so as to run away from people's eyes. But after watching this movie i am deeply enthralled and also motivated to fight inner demons of fear in me and to emerge as a person i am and which i am ought to be .Thanks for Ben Affleck and Matt Damon to bring such a script which is so touching and a path finder for people who are making their abilities go redundant just because of some stupid psychological problem

This film easily ranks as one of my all time favorites. The script is brilliant, the performances are genuine and powerful. Actually, powerful is the best word to describe this film. After the first viewing, I felt an overwhelming aftertaste of euphoria. There are so many valuable life lessons you can glean from this tale of a "super smart" yet troubled young man (Matt Damon)who finds the complicated simple yet the fundamental aspects of social human interaction very difficult. Given the fact that Matt Damon also co-wrote the screenplay (while in his early 20's) with real life pal and co-star Ben Affleck is even more impressive. I consistently find myself shocked to hear that some have not yet experienced this gem. If you love movies, you must see this movie. I can't seem to stop singing it's praises even as it approaches the films ten year mark.In short, if you haven't already seen this film, find some quiet time, rent it and savor one of the highlights of cinematic history.

I rented this movie a week ago, not expecting too much from it. After viewing this movie I was blown away. I thought the acting was exceptional. Robin Williams made easily the best performance of his career. Being that this movie was basically the start of both Matt Damon and Ben Affleck's careers, it was a great start for both of them. If the performance by Matt Damon is not Best Actor material, then I have never seen it.The movie is about a janitor at MIT, named Will Hunting (Damon) who is a mathematical genius. He has solved a couple of equations off of chalkboards that none of the students at MIT could solve. For one reason or another, he would rather go out and drink, although underage, with his buddies (Affleck and company) than do something with his life, other than work as a janitor. As he has been abused all of his life, he seeks guidance in his life from a psychiatrist named Sean Maguire (Best Supporting Actor Williams).This movie is definitely one of my top 20 favorite movies of all time. If you catch it on TV, or have to rent it, do not miss this movie. This is the real Best Picture of 1997. 9/10 stars

Fantastic acting, writing, and directing. Robin Williams transitions from his comedy normality to the engaging, layered, and connected realm of drama. Matt Damon and Ben Affleck have scripted a mater piece with Damon delivering a performance that, like wine, ages into perfection, and Affleck secures a remarkable performance.I have watched this film more than 300 times and relate to the character of Will (his contextualization of capability on mathematical terminology within the distinct realm of infinite discovery and capacity and yet his loss of identity due to various personal life experiences and the broader scope of identity in the environmental dichotomy of characters and influences. WIll Hunting is one of the most brilliant characters in cinematic history. Despite his unique disposition, he is human and we can relate to him, as the audience. We root for him to win. We root for him to find himself.

This is one of the most genuine movies i've ever seen.  It's not perfect - on the contrary, it feels kind of rough.  But it's just a really honest movie.  You can tell it wasn't polluted by the big budget Hollywood mentality like so many movies nowadays are.  Although I'm skeptical that this movie really deserves a 10 from an artistic perspective, I don't regret my vote, because I think this movie is the embodiment of what moviemaking is all about.  It tells an incredible, human story in an honest, deep, and very enthralling fashion.  Also, I think the acting is just amazing, *especially* by Matt Damon, Robin Williams, and Minnie Driver.  I think it's great that Affleck and Damon wrote the script and followed through with getting it made...  Definitely a movie worth watching, for casual moviegoers and hardcore movie buffs alike.

Review title: How did this film manage to get on the top 250?
Review_body: While the acting is good, the story is hardly likely and contains inconsistencies. Will's mathematical "proofs" are really "solutions" to problems. The writers clearly know nothing of their subject matter, and have failed to consult sufficiently in an area outside their expertise. Furthermore, the "psychological" side of the story is simple and really contains nothing new or interesting (basically, it's the story of a normal guy who's had some issues in his life, who reads avidly and has a great interest in math, yet somehow does not even know the names of the theorems he makes use of in his "proofs"). Wishful thinking from people with little to no background in science, and ignorant enough to believe that Will's level of knowledge is possible without study. I put this movie on the same level as "The Girl Next Door": an adolescent movie whose entertainment value is due primarily to the distraction in provides.

Review title: Hell, it was a good movie.
Review_body: While plot wise it wasn't really that innovative, it more than made up for it in the dialogue.  I still refuse to believe those f***ers Damen and Afleck wrote it themselves but until its proven false, I will give credit where it is deserved.  The dialogue was riveting, it really was.  Gus Van Sant also did a good job adding feeling and color where dialogue was absent. Hell, even the score chosen was appropriate for the scenes they portrayed. Williams did a tremendous outshine everyone job acting, and even Afleck and Damen were far from shabby.  And as much as we all like to hate Driver, she too was ok I guess.  The movie from start to finish was told smoothly and was crafted deliberately.  Still, it was those small tidbits of dialogue that made the movie incredible and unique.  Few can deny the power of the script.

Review title: Subtle and beautiful in most ways, unbelievable in others.
Review_body: I can't believe how black and white the reviews on here are for this film. People either seem to think it perfect, or terrible. I have neither of these views - it was however a very good film. Not in my top 10, but certainly in the top 100.It IS moving, it HAS got some beautiful and believable dialogue and it is very well acted by virtually all concerned. My favourite part being Robin William's dressing down of will: "And I'd ask you about war, you'd probably throw Shakespeare at me, right, 'once more unto the breach dear friends.' But you've never been near one. You've never held your best friend's head in your lap, watch him gasp his last breath looking to you for help. I'd ask you about love, you'd probably quote me a sonnet..." etc. Well written! However, the main flaw in my opinion is Matt's character. He is simply too well rounded a genius, it's unbelievable and a little arrogant of the two writers. He has real emotional flaws and that's all dandy, but personally I think he should have been out-quoted by the guy in the Harvard bar and still got the girl anyway for sticking up for his friend. I think he could have shown even more vulnerability by being really knocked by not being the best at everything. Oh well, a missed opportunity.Put it this way I don't know many geniuses who haven't got a blind spot in current affairs or history or social skills or SOMETHING. Saying that, the way he holds himself back with his self destructive behaviour is classic and very well portrayed.It's a film I will definitely watch many times and I suggest you do too. This film is boring only in the same way the night sky is boring... it depends how deep you are willing to look and how much you are willing to think.

Now it is very rare that I give a film 10/10 because I believe that no film can be 'perfect' - but for the first time I believe I have found a genuine 10.Featuring two of my favourite actors, Matt Damon and Robin Williams, I was already optimistic about the film and the acting did not disappoint. Everything the actors did and said was so suitable to their characters and it was clear that they had an overwhelming understanding of the characters they were playing.The plot was thoughtful but in no way slow. It contained that balance that all great films need of comedy, romance, drama, friendship and raw emotion. This balance was so well distributed that it meant one could cry (as I did) at an emotional scene but could then be comforted by a later scene with some comedy.The film is one of absolute brilliance, which teaches an important lesson about life. It will go down as a classic in my books. I've seen a lot of films - and I mean a lot - but this will forever hold a place in my 5 all time favourite films.A must see for anyone and everyone.

As a Christian I try my hardest not to watch movies that have no moral value. From the previews I was eager to see Good Will Hunting, however from word of mouth I heard that it was full of cussing and violence. Well the rumors got the best of me and tragically I did not see this wonderful movie until a little over a year ago. My friend Maggie told me I had to see it that she watched it on tv. Maggie being my best friend, I listened. I rented the movie and watched it. WOW! I have never been so impressed with a movie in all my movie watching life. (And I watch ALOT of movies.) This movie is the best written, best acted, best directed, and best depiction of real human emotion I've seen to date. Not only does it deal with actual problems that go deeper than "I'm in love with Bobby but he loves Barbra Anne!" but it also shows how a real human being would deal with these problems. Truthfully this is one of the greatest movies of all time, and honstly yes there is a considerable amount of cussing and there is some violence. Still I would recomend this flick to any one of my friends, Christian or not. Well there's my two cents, don't spend it all in one palce now.

The first thing that draw my attention when I opened this movie on IMDb was this lovely, warm picture of Matt Damon and Robin Williams. By the expression on their faces, it seemed like a movie filled with emotions and after seeing it I realized how right I had been. The plot of the movie is so well organized. That's the first thing that comes to my mind. They devoted enough time for every aspect of Will's character. Nothing was done in haste. First half of the movie is about his intelligence, about him and his Professor trying to improve his skills. And the other half highlights completely different side of him. It shows wide range of emotions that we hadn't known he felt. That even he hadn't known he felt. Throughout the movie, the story is developing slowly but surely and it's full of catchy lines and witty phrases. Another amazing thing about this movie is his excellence, Robin Williams. His portrayal of Sean Maguire is one of the best I've ever seen. And also, character lived up to all my expectations. I had known that Robin is a psychologist before watching the movie, and I find such characters highly entertaining, but this one is, by far, my favourite. So intelligent man, and yet, full of pain because of the loss he had suffered. His love for his wife tugged at my heartstrings and made me cry from time to time. The way he talked about meeting her for the first time is, in my opinion, what love should be. Though annoying he may seem, Prof. Gerald is not all that bad, in my opinion. Even though he completely neglected the emotional part of Will and was more concentrated on enhancing his skills, he had best interest in his heart for Will and I don't see that as a bad thing. He knows that life is hard and thinks that Will should use his smartness he was endowed with as much as he can.In my humble opinion, mixture of these two characters, Sean and Gerald, is the best parent Will could have ever had. The realistic one and sensitive one.I must admit, to my shame, that before this movie I had never seen any movie starring Matt Damon, but he blew me away. His performance was impeccable. And Will .. oh, Will is just so amazing. No super- intelligent character has ever been that adorable. That scene where he degrades that Mr. "know-it-all" from Harvard was both charming and funny. Skylar and him are also adorable and one of the most natural screen couples I have ever seen. And the best thing is that in the end, with all bad things that have happened to him in life and all doubts he had in the movie, he gets a happy ending.Also, the relationship between Will and Sean is so well-written. When they met Will was so arrogant, thinking he knows it all and started insulting Sean and making false presumptions about his life. Even though it offended him, he saw it as a challenge. He saw a kid who desperately needed help and accepted to see him in the future. The scene on the bench, in front of a lake is, the most touching and beautiful scenes ever made. Damon and Affleck are true artists for making this scene. And it was also the turning point for this relationship – that's where Will realized that there's more to that man that he had previously thought. Not to mention "It's not your fault" part of the movie. The more he repeated that sentence the more I was falling in love with the movie. So powerful and , as I had mentioned, artistic.In a word, the best movie I have ever seen and that's why I'm giving it a ten.

This is trite, formulaic rubbish. Why people find this so entertaining is quite beyond me. The writing is immature at best. I read an early draft online and it actually contained an old, and not particularly funny, joke which clearly was going to be passed off as original material before someone obviously stepped and edited it out of the script. For me that says it all. Little imagination, laughably hackneyed worn out characters and a plot with more holes in it than a sieve.We are expected to swallow the fact that he knows more about law, history, mathematics and English literature than the 'experts' we are haplessly presented with in these various fields. OK but how on earth does he achieve this from the public library while holding down a full time job and apparently cultivating lasting friendships with the ne'erdowells with whom he associates, relationships, we are also expected to believe led him regularly into trouble with the authorities?Anyone who knows the 'genius fallen by the wayside' scenario in real life knows only too well that there is never a happy ending. There is no sweet little Robin Williamsesque professor just waiting in the background to help him through it all. It is just painfully stupid Hollywood fluff, he even gets the girl. The only thing he doesn't do is ride off into the sunset on a white horse. I think it was actually a car.

This movie was so boring. My friend and I had a marker fight in the back of the theater, we were so bored. Usually, I love anything Robin Williams is in. While I liked his performance, the rest of the actors and the movie, by definition blew. The plot was slow, the character development was slow. Everything was slow and boring. I am so glad I didn't pay for it, because I would have demanded my money back. I cant remember the last time I ever wasted two hours. I only went because I had a free pass. I am infinitely glad that Damon and Affleck haven't written anything so rampantly horrible since. One good thing about it was, that it cant get much worse than that, and their future attempts can only get better, cant they?

Between Matt Damon and Robin Williams, watching this movie was a no brainer
One of my all time favorite movies. Fantastic script, actors and plot. Lost count on how many times I have watched this movie and I always see something different.

It's interesting to look back a movie that was produced almost 20 years back - pure luck browsing through Netflix! The plot is simple but soul-touching. Matt Damon was so young and handsome back then! He perfectly portrayed the role of a genius but confused young man. Although it is somehow hard to believe that there is actually someone born with that kind of gift. The personality of the character is not attractive at the beginning, but with the help from the psychologist, he eventually opened up himself and was able to live up following his heart. The ending is beautiful. Guess there is no exception before true love.

Gus Van Sant first caught my attention when I sat down with some friends to watch "Last Days", a biographical movie about the final days of Nirvana singer Kurt Cobain. The movie was beautifully done, with many long and winding scenes shot in single takes that seemed to capture Cobain's final environment and mindset perfectly. It wouldn't be long before I would see his similarly styled drama "Elephant" about the events leading up to a school shooting. I knew he directed "Good Will Hunting" but somehow its taken me 17 years to finally sit down to watch it in its entirety, and I am so glad I finally was able to scratch this gem-- number 130 on the IMDb top 250-- off of the list.Hot-headed adult orphan Will Hunting (Matt Damon) leads a pretty normal life for a South Boston reprobate: between his janitorial job at MIT and getting shmacked with his buddies (Ben and Casey Affleck) at his local watering hole, Will is pretty unremarkable—except that he's a genius, an inexplicable phenom that has a wealth of knowledge about many topics, but due to his hard-knocks upbringing, never had any substantial education. When he starts surreptitiously solving the complex equations that are posted in the MIT halls to challenge the students, he catches the attention of mathematics professor Gerald Lambeau (Stellan Skarsgard). Gerry learns that Will is in trouble with the law, and is able to make a plea with the judge: In leau of jail time, Will has to study mathematics with Gerry and go to routine therapy. After many failed attempts with a number of therapists, Gerry calls on his former college roommate and psychology professor, Sean Maguire (Robin Williams) to help. After butting heads initially, Will and Sean start to slowly solve the one problem that Will can't—his own internal struggle.This film is a wonderful examination of love, manhood, and socioeconomic status set to a gorgeous soundtrack (Danny Elfman). The relationship between Damon and Williams is priceless and powerful, beautifully scripted and masterfully executed (Williams won the Oscar that year for Best Supporting Actor with this role), and the addition of Minnie Driver is, to me, the icing on the proverbial cake. She is a beautiful and quirky addition to the cast and she and Damon are comfortable and charismatic together (her character was based on Damon's then girlfriend who left him for Metallica drummer Lars Ulrich just before filming). The script is a taut psychological ballet, with some of the best monologues I've heard in a good long while (Damon's rant about hitting the hash pipe and joining the National Guard especially!) To be completely honest, I think that the addition of the Affleck brothers brought this picture down a peg, though not nearly enough to weigh it down in a major way.

Review title: One of the Best Movies Ever Made
Review_body: This is personally, my favorite movie ever. It contains everything you've ever wanted in a film, from great character development, amazing dialog, funny scenes, beautiful cinematography, and impactive moments. Matt Damon plays a genius from the south side of Boston who spends the majority of his time hanging out with his degenerate group of friends who get into fights among other things. He is picked up by a professor who recognizes his genius, and is sent to work with Robin Williams in order to get his mental state up to a good level. After conflict and resolution, Damon and Williams end up working together and everyone is happy.The reason I love this so movie so much is because of the range of emotion displayed throughout. The scene in the park makes me cry every time, and I am not ashamed to say it.You really have to go check out the movie if you haven't already.

Review title: Excellent work and a brilliant story!
Review_body: I was postponing watching this movie as i thought it wouldn't be so incredible, but contrary to what i expected this movie is one of the greatest that I've ever watched. *This part may contain some spoilers* Will, the orphan genius who had a childhood problems because of his adoptive alcoholic father who's apparently used to kinda torture him, he appeared to have fear of abandonment issues due to the fact that he was abandoned from one of his parents which later affected his personality and made him defensive and a bit aggressive. Despite all of this psychological problems, Will appeared to have a brilliant mind in all fields and not only math. Later in some event in the movie Will sees a guy who he appeared to have some old nursery problems with, Will decided to take revenge, which reflects that his personality is really affected by some memories from the past. He gets arrested and thanks to that he meets the professor who wants to make Will take advantage of his brilliant mind. But to make him do that will had to see a therapist to get rid of his "aggressive personality" first. A bunch of therapist failed to communicate with Will due to the fact that he is the one who analyzes their personalities and not the opposite. But prof Gerald knew the one who could communicate with Will and make him reveal what's inside his heart, an old friend called Sean, who later became a close friend of Will's. I really enjoyed every moment of this movie, brilliant story, excellent acting, and a wonderful sequence of events.

I saw it when I was 1,4 saw it again yesterday (I'm 22 now) and boy....had I missed out on so much when I was 14. Many people remember this movie for the "bar scene" where Will Hunting knocks out the Harvard snob with his intelligence or the "chalk board scene" where Will answers the extremely difficult mathematical questions but in essence, the "genius" thing is really just a cream on top. What the movie really delved into and really focused on, was the essence of "life". To ME, it truly described what "life" was and how it really approaches people so differently yet moves them all the same. I think the most brilliant thing about this movie was that the characters were all developed so well. We know the characters, we know them so much that we can write a whole skit with their personalities. The character development of each and every character was so vivid yet their depiction wasn't forced or effortful. The depiction was so subtle, yet so strong that they could say a few words but they would tell you a thousand. Every single line of the movie was gold. I don't even know where to start. So many memorable and meaningful quotes yet none of them were cheesy. I think that Stellan Skarsgård's character was underrated honestly. The way he looked at Will's work reminded me of the scene from Amadeus where Salieri takes one look at Mozart's work (work that only few can discern its pure magnificence) and just gazes at awe at the same time reeking with jealousy. Yet the professor doesn't look at Will with jealousy but almost protects him like his own child, all the while determined to let this genius be known. He reminds me of something a parent would do when they realise their child is a prodigy. They wouldn't try to understand or let him/her be free but would try to do exactly what the professor did. Only a third person like Sean would be able to pry deep into the child's mind to allow the child be free. Also I think the main reason Will stuck with Sean (brilliantly played by Robin Williams) on the whole counseling thing was because Will saw a bit of himself in Sean and Sean obviously saw a bit of himself in Will. Anyways the script was magnificent the character development was just so beautiful and the movie was just so effortless yet so sublime.Some people argue that the movie was "predictable" and that it was "unrealistic" which I think was a real hit in the head for me. "Predictable"? I mean were you here to watch some sci-fi movie or did you think this would have a "twist-ending" and suddenly Will would be abducted by some aliens because usually movies like this that deal with "life-situations" are PREDICABLE obviously. Also, honestly, I don't see how this was so predictable in that Will might have become a really famous and successful person in the ending other than going to find his lover which would have made the movie really cheesy. Also given that this movie is predictable yet keeps the audience stuck to their chairs eyes glued to the screen proves that it's all that good. "unrealistic" hmmmm.......honestly, I have seen veryyyyyy unrealistic child prodigies in real life and Matt Damon's character is not really that unrealistic. I mean on the movie industries unrealistic scale, this movie would scale a 0 out of 10, because it's that realistic. Overall, best movie ever. It kept me thinking and it grew onto me and made me really give Life a hard look in the eye.

Review title: A mildly inspiring movie with solid writing
Review_body: Good Will Hunting is a great film with an inspiring message. As I was watching this film for the first time in seventh grade, I felt extremely empowered and emotional. I'm sure I wouldn't have the same reaction now, but this film holds a very special nostalgic place in my memory.The movie is very quotable, with famous lines like " you like apples", etc. The story can be cliché at times, but it overall it does this to be as relate able as possible, similar to the book the alchemist. Overall, I felt this film is a 9/10, because of it's nostalgic value, good writing, and solid jokes.

i found it really overrated, i mean the movie was very slow & felt like they were stretching the scenes, they could have used the concept a lot better but, i think in the old times this was the kind of movies people liked, but today us the new generation will find it extremely boring. so to sum it up, if you are born after 2000 you won't like it. i am sorry if it hurts

Review title: Good humor, good content, and good lines
Review_body: I don't know how anyone could not appreciate this movie. It has some of the most inspiring lines about how to live life. There are so many people who are so concerned about success and making a lot of money and the image of success. People don't think about whether or not they are doing something they love to do. You wont see Ben Afleck this good in any other movie, and Robin Williams is outstanding. It is a movie. Not all characters are supposed to be perfect;as long as the themes of the movie are communicated and you leave the movie feeling a natural high (you probably will) then the director has done his job. This should be seen by everyone!

Review title: How to know right from wrong?
Review_body: I saw this movie only recently, years after it was first released.For me this was a movie about a psychologist trying to help a genius young man who was about to make the most important decisions in his life, but didn't have the ability or the tools to recognize this and make the right choices. He was lacking the guiding principles in his life.Robin Williams, the psychologist, argued that only being a genius is not enough to make a person successful and happy, and he gave Unabomber as an example, who was a mathematical genius.The psychologist helped Matt (with a bit of forcing) to get rid of all the layers of pretentiousness, arrogance, and the masks he wear and finally touch where it hurts deep inside. Matt had to feel his hurt, realize the absence of his guiding principles, or whatever you want to call "not even knowing what he wants out of life", before he can start the healing process.When we make choices in life, our decisions are partially influenced by what we have learned while growing up. We learn the right from wrong mainly from our parents. In the absence of parents, teachers, relatives, the community or the religion provide us the guidance we need. Having been an orphan, and not having had a stable foster family, Matt didn't have a solid upbringing. The psychologist was concerned that, this genius, if not guided correctly, may become a loser, or may become a danger to himself and to the society.It was a great movie, recommend it everybody but especially to parents.

Moving, but will consider it a flick, so I only recommend it if you classify yourself as a typical audience member who does not pay attention to realism. Admittedly, I fall into this category.I was most interested in the therapy aspects of the show. As an inexperienced psychology student (I'm only as old as the movie, I know close to nothing), I've been curious about the life of a clinical psychologist (or as popular culture may call it, a 'shrink'). This show probably romanticises the true nature of clinical work. Sure, it can be fulfilling, but I doubt it'll be as glamorous as portrayed by Robin Williams. Chatting with the client, instinctively knowing the way around him, followed by a success story - sounds a bit too much like a 'movie', but then again, it is... I'm still interested in clinical psychology though. I'm glad this film explicates the beauty of the field.Despite this, I still enjoyed my 2 hours in front of the screen. It's cathartic for those like me who want to feel emotionally polarised for a moment. That's the nature of the drama genre - forget subtlety once in a while, draw yourself away from reality, and allow your intuition and emotions to develop.
Feel like I wasted 2 hours on this. I would not recommend to watch it

The dialogues were so incredible that I can't recall so many films with dialogues this much great! Specially the ones between Sean and Will! Seriousness, beauty, laugh and many good staff you wanna see and here are there for you in their dialogues.
Guess it deserved the best screenplay of the year

Main problem of film is realization of protagonist through the movie. The movie tries to establish and ideology about arrogance, experience, genius, intelligentsia, etc.
You have to educate yourself by teacher or material or writing to understand mathematics. And you have to this with formal learning. In film, our extremely genius boy easily freestyle the field of mathematics. I have to sample a piece from movie, in a dialogue, Professor Lambeau corrects the answer of our genius boy, and says "I see you used Maclaurin here.". And boy replies with "Yeah, I don't know what you call it, but...". This is pure manipulation. The director and film controls behavior of audience because of perception of mathematics influenced what really mathematics is. Again our boy free-styling mathematics alike hip-hop and overcomes the situation once again. An ugly deus ex machina. I have to imply, I'm not saying people cannot be educated without a college. But field like mathematics, needs to formal education and strict instructions. When you are doing math, there are many precautions, preparations, restrictions and so on. Just look the term, Poincaré conjecture and solution of it.And some people might say, don't stick these details too much, see the general idea of movie. OK fellas, I have to admit, only shining thing about the movie, the Sean Maguire aka 6th psychologist against Bad Will Hunting. This man may seem cliche, grown-man, stoic character but I have to credit, the man is good. The message of this character is understandable and clear. Also movie tries to put a better position of him, rather than genius-one. Several times, we have seen, the old man destroys the kid, with his posture. But in the end, movie declares Will Hunting is good and lovable. And foreshadowing of the movie was awful.

I first saw this movie about a year ago, and it still amazes me now. The screenplay is really well written, the cast is great (specificaly Robin Williams), and superbly directed. The movie had me almost crying at least twice, and has a excellent way of keeping you into the story all the way. Minnie Driver gives a good performance too, and I think she should have gotten the Oscar for Best Supporting Actress.Personally, I think the only thing wrong with this film is the language, which leaves your ears ringing after a while. In short, awesome movie, great acting, superb screenplay, and overall inspiring.

If something is really call perfection that is that movie. A beautiful story line , beautiful acting , beautiful direction and a massage the real meaning off happiness which not come by money or repution it come by love.

Um... Maybe I just didn't get it... but everyone thinks i am a freak with no soul because i hated this movie...I will tell you why i hated it...First off, i began to literally fall asleep in the middle of the movie because this movie was very very boring. The story absolutely sucked. I don't see how these guys won a best screenplay for this. The dialogue was painfully forced and unrealistic--am I supposed to laugh at the "how do you like them apples line".. am i supposed to feel a sense of accomplishment for the character? Instead with that line, and in fact that whole scene and the rest of the movie had me saying "WTF?????"Not to mention that scene in the bar again, but who has conversations at a bar like that? Not even Harvard attendees talk like that at a bar--they are busy doing keg stands and playing beer pong.Where were the basic elements of a good story in this? Rising action--climax--falling action--character development--protagonist--antagonist. Is anyone with me on this...Or am I alone in the world?

A great story full of twists and turns, filled with lessons for a lifetime. This was and still is an extraordinary piece by Matt and Ben. Also from the screenwriting point , this one is one of a kind. So effectivelly written with its characters really show their feelings without telling it. Just best of the best.

Review title: The human mindset as an open book.
Review_body: A lot of people are trying to hide their feelings behind their behaviour like Matt in this movie. When you went through difficult times, you never felt love, you don't know what unconditional guidance means you are afraid of many things but the most from your own self.This movie shows us the mindset and the feelings behind the "titles", it shows us what human connection means and how difficult is to achieve it!The plot is more than a story about a genius guy and a success story, it's a diamond of psychology into two hours.I definitely recommend it and I also recommend to see the real meaning and not just the affairs.

Review title: Genius doesn't know how to mop a floor
Review_body: Awful, nauseating, egotistical, pretentious, amateurish. With God-Like Intelligence and Wisdom, Will Hunting's character is established as he mops the school floor. Without wringing the mop or placing a warning sign for slippery surface, Will carelessly slops water toward several students. If he was so intelligent, it seems to me that he would be able to mop a floor correctly. This is truly a horrible movie on many levels. How does he know everything? We don't see him reading and amassing his encyclopedic knowledge. It appears that Matt Damon spends more time grooming his cute hair-do than perusing mathematics tomes at the library. Ben Affleck was terrible..he is truly a bad actor. Robin Williams was the only bright spot in this black hole of a movie. The award Good Will Hunting should have received was the Golden Turkey Award.

Review title: A master piece that will wake you up
Review_body:
It's the first time I've ever write a film review even I feel like I really should starting to do it for such a long time.
I've heard tones of good reviews on this film but I just watched it now, when the pandemic has been on for almost half a year and people have been questioning themselves a lot recently including me. During this hard time I felt confused, lost , angry, disappointed and negative, all these emotions and feelings are the ones that I've never imagined that I would be like when I thought about it.
While I was watching it, I couldn't bear my tears at all from about 40 mins. It reminds me of all those tiny things from the past, failed relationships, people that I've missed and moments that I regret. Your struggled feelings slowly burned up with Will all the way to the climax because you understand exactly how he feels, you understand those hard journeys that make him and you who you are today, but meanwhile, you still want to see and anxious to see him makes the decision that you know what is right.
I'm having a very bittersweet feeling right now and I guess this also explains perfectly why films are so powerful, what a great script, what a character building. I love how Matt used the script shows off a bit side of his English education background with small parts like mentioning about Oliver Twist by Charles Dickens, Skyler as the British girlfriend, all little details were very nicely putted.
I just wanted to say how lucky Will is to have these people around him, his friends, met the Gerry who found his talents and cherished it so much who would do everything to keep it up, and Sean who smartly guides him all the way and also truly understands him, and of course Skyler, a lovely vivid soul with a brave, strong and beautiful heart. All character's personalities are so different and so lively, they're all just like reflections of people around us in the real life, all these lead me to the final question that, did we really cherished our life well enough? If not why don't we just start doing it now? It's never too late.

Review title: One of, if not the best movie ever made.
Review_body: Good Will Hunting is one of the most beautifully written, directed, and acted movies there has ever been. I've read the screenplay and seen the movie numerous times, and I can tell you that there has never been a more original film. My love of this film is one of the reasons that I hate Titanic so much. Good Will Hunting deserved all of the Academy Awards that it was nominated for, more even. It was one of the happiest moments of my life when I saw Matt Damon, Ben Affleck, and Robin Williams accepting their Oscars. No one has ever deserved them more. I feel sorry for Minnie Driver though. She deserved her Oscar much more than Kim Basinger did. Kim was barely in any of L.A. Confidential, while Minnie was one of the most important characters. They all deserve Oscars.

This movie is very touching.There are a lot of very impressive dialogues especially the one when Sean and Will talked together in the park and the one where Will explained why he shouldn't work for the NSA.

Review title: Despite the strong language, an excellent script and complex characters.
Review_body: As a film buff coming from a conservative background, I find myself struggling to evaluate honestly films containing strong language, particularly when it appears in such abundance as in this film.  But, bearing in mind that such language is endemic to the principal characters in the film, I found myself thoroughly entranced by Will's character development throughout the film.  The script and attendant dialogue carry the viewer along logically, both with respect to Will but also the Robin Williams character.  The development of these two fully-realized characters as their interactions cross provides real insight into the complexities of human nature. The supporting roles of the maths professor and the Minnie Driver characters only add to the painful but honest reality of this film.

Review title: A wonderful, dialogue driven coming of age story
Review_body: Personally, I found this movie to be a refreshing change from movies we see nowadays. Before seeing it I thought the basic premise was nothing new but Robin Williams might make it an interesting movie. I was delightedly surprised. Matt Damon pulled off a magnificent performance in a not-so-new character type. I found the plot to be a wonderful vehicle for the outstanding dialogue that made the movie so rewatchable for me. The screenplay absolutely deserved the Oscar. Robin Williams had easily one of the best performances of his career (at least as powerful as Dead Poet's Society if not more so). He poured a lot of emotion into a character just as complicated as Damon's. The connection between Williams' character and Damon's was powerful. Minnie Driver delivered a wonderful performance as Damon's love interest. Stellan Skaarsgard, though I don't recall another movie he has been, also played a complicated role as sort of a mental mentor to Damon. But my hat is off to Ben Affleck. This was the first movie I saw him in and his presence on screen was amazing. He is responsible for possibly my favorite scene in the movie, the scene where he tells Will Hunting that he doesn't "owe it to himself, you owe it to me." I believe he took the role as best friend to a new level. He also has a wonderful scene where he has to basically just stand there and let us know what is going on in his mind. I hope to see him around a lot in the future. This movie is wonderfully cast and brought me back again and again.

Review title: Good Will Hunting was the best picture of 1997!
Review_body: I liked Titanic, but it was a silly film when compared to Good Will Hunting. This movie was so emotional and moving.  It was still on my mind three weeks after I first saw it.  The script was original, and the acting was beyond phenomenal.  Good Will Hunting should have won the Oscar for Best Picture of 1997.

Well, for all of you out there who love the F word and MF, this movie is for you.   For anyone who desires a storyline, this one is quite minimal.  Who wants to hear the F word for a whole movie?  If cursing as well as a bonus of bad actors is a movie to you, then see it.  The ironic thing is that I don't mind cursing in a movie so long it's to prove a point; but in this movie, it was meant to be simply crude and I saw no point in it.The story seemed to open up with a reasonable plot, but went nowhere.  I suppose it went downhill the more I saw a preppy type of guy claimed to be a genius, yet making idiotic decisions in life.  I'm sorry, but I just can't even imagine Matt Damon as any sort of a genius.  (sheesh, even the size of his vocabulary is obviously limited to curse words only)The reason so many people like this movie has to be because of the big name actors.  What teenage girl doesn't want to see Matt Damon?  Of course, when he's a main actor in a movie, girls go crazy for him as well as Ben Affleck. With such "good looking guys", what girl wouldn't go crazy for it?The bottom line for this movie is that it's horrible and should realistically be rated NC-17 for the language let alone the horrible acting.

Review title: An over-rated drama for popular culture
Review_body: It's very predictable that a movie like this would soon be placed into that undefined category of "good" recent movies, which includes any film having the smallest bit of sincerity and meaning. The fact that the popular trend is toward the visual and that special effects are replacing plots and subtle nuances tends to lead the average viewer to the opinion that any film that attempts these is a grand effort. This is not true. "Good Will Hunting" does not even have a well-defined plot, but that fits into the movie acceptably: it's an extraordinary man's search for himself through love, psychoanalysis, and philosophy. The premier problem is that the movie overplays it's best card: Matt Damon's(character's) incredible brain. There is a certain point at which the audience should halt its fascination at his mental profencies and sigh in boredom. It's unfortunate that this was not the case for most theaters. Though the meaning of life and gifted individuals are good themes for movies, they are not original, and this "tear-jerker" makes no unique contributions to either idea. In fact, if you want to see real meaning in a popular movie, rent "Rocky", a title which many supposed "film experts" would probably not want to admit conveys deeper human meaning than most "good" movies, like (appropriately) Good Will Hunting. Shame on you,  movie fans, for falling in love with such a butchered attempt at profundity.

Every movie has a theme that has been used before in a movie. Only after you have seen this movie completely the behaviour of Will starts to make sense. And even than, the depth of his troubled life isn't totally clear. This movie is full of mental challenges. Brilliant written conversations constantly change your perspective to the story. In a nutshell: bit by bit you start to understand you can't possibly understand what Will's life is about.

Review title: Implausible,stupid movie- "just because your a genius doesn't mean that you can't be super cool too"
Review_body: I got dragged to see this movie and i knew i was in trouble in the first few minutes of the film. A seemingly average guy working as a janitor is really a gifted, brilliant, but troubled young man.I hated this stupid movie so much, that i hoped Damon's character in Saving Private Ryan would be captured by the germans and tortured to death.

Review title: Wonderful film with overuse of bad language.
Review_body: I don't usually mind the "F" word, but the use in this movie makes it embarrasing to watch with others.  Not a family film.  Wonderfully acted, it's a film with very good feeling.. but impossible to recommend to friends because of the language.. really sad not to be able to do so.

I don't often comment on films, just vote, but this one got to me in so many ways.  I had to see it three times and speak to 10+ friends before I figured it out.  We all see a little of us in one of these people and it is a little scary.  A friend pointed out my similar problems with relationships as Will in the movie.A wonderfully written, (can they repeat?) great acting, and it makes you think.  What more can you want.  Rent it, watch it twice, and think about it.

Review title: Truly, a film that deserves the praise it's received.
Review_body: I've been a fan of Matt Damon and Ben Affleck for several years, and Robil Williams has been number one, as far as I'm concerned in everything he's done. This film from the beginning gripped my full attention. It's as if the three stars referenced above really weren't actors in the film. It was real life. No one would be noticed if they tried to redo this film. Life today is very hard, and scenes as depicted here are probably common. Every one in a while it's a good thing to try to convey to the public that we're all alike and from time to time show a glimpse of the extraordinary in their lives, but can't seem to get their message out. Here, Matt Damon, is an example of someone like this. He's fortunate to receive the help he needs. It's not easy, as the film shows, but Robil Williams is the one (that everyone of us needs) who finally breaks thru to truly help someone who is Good, Will Hunting.

This movie is very very silly. The worn-out concept of the enfant terrible is mixed with the even more worn-out concept of boy-genius in this pretentious flick by a group of people who ought to know better.

Review title: An injection of motivation and spine-tingling inspiration.
Review_body: It didn't have bombs.  It didn't have comets.  And it didn't have a gigantic, sinking boat.  Bottom line?  Didn't need it.  In this inspiring, fantasy-wrought screenplay brought to life, Ben Affleck and Matt Damon prove that a down-to-earth, low-budget film can capture magnificence without all the special effects and larger than life cinematography.  With Gus Van Sant, the envisioner of the movie, and the unsurprisingly superb Danny Elfman behind the musical wheel, Good Will Hunting deserved the Oscar for Best Picture.  Titanic was predictable and true; Good Will Hunting offered a new story to the genre of fantasy screenplays, and it was evident in its winning Best Original Screenplay.  As deserving as this was, the Academy fell far short of a consolation prize when it denied it Best Picture.  See this movie and follow along with Will on his magical "hunt" for a future and security.

Review title: By far one of my top 5 movies to date!!!
Review_body: This movie is in my top 5 possibly even top 3 because one people can relate to the story. Two the acting is initiated well. good flow maybe a little bit slow in the beginning but totally worth watching through! I hands down recommend this movie :)

There was an individual who talked about the unbelievability of this Movie, how Will was a math prodigy with only little formal education. He also said it isn't logical because he himself was a math God, and he would know. Well, to you, get over yourself, the movie was great! Go bowling With Professor Lambeau and have a nice conversation about "exciting math theory." I think it is definitely believable, hence the word PRODIGY. Some people don't like the fact that they aren't the smartest human being in the world. This upsets them, so they must claim "fallacy" to make themselves feel better. Yeah, Hollywood exaggerates, get used to it. Anyway, this movie is definitely a must see for anyone that can enjoy a movie without getting offended that there actually might be a genius in the world, and who can enjoy a beautifully made Film!

I see a movie with Matt Damon and Ben Affleck and I tend to drift away from it but this film was different. Matt and Ben tend to be dry, boring actors and never tend to be in very interesting films. They fit into the characters so well you would think they were actually real people. Although I never really enjoy movies with either of these actors I thought this film was very well done. I give it a 10/10! A film of brilliance, heartbreak, rebellion, and a wild adventure. Knowing that they directed this movie I thought the plot would be awful but it really captured the essence of human nature. Matt and Ben really got into character and captured the true personality of two boys from 1980"s South Boston. From roaming the streets, bar fights, to the accents and the culture.Will is a young boy at the bottom of the social pyramid who has lived a lonely, abusive life. He works as a janitor at MIT but is yet extremely intelligent and begins solving their problems that not even the professors could do. Because of his lifestyle and who he is it's not okay for him to express his intelligents to society.This film tells a story that is quite common yet is hidden from the world. Will (Matt) is highly intelligent yet he never puts it to use. People continue to push him to move forward and use his abilities yet he chooses not to. He's at the bottom of the social pyramid but has the ability to be at the top. People read into him and he feels threatened by that so he tries to outsmart them by reading deeper into them tearing them apart. Just like any movie there is always a girl but it isn't all lovey dovey. This movie captures the struggle of love in which he struggles with from his early childhood. Will picks up a girl at the bar and they talk and grow closer until she falls in love with him. She tries to push him to do something with his abilities and be a part of his life but that scares him so he tells her he doesn't love her even though he truly does. He fears being loved and hurting her.This movie really deals about vulnerability, fear, friendship, and of course love. Will feels vulnerable being loved by a woman. A relationship would make him have to open up in which he fears because he feels as if he doesn't deserve love. He fears the judgement. Robin shows how powerful love really is by talking about his wife whom even though is dead he constantly cherishes their moments together and shares them, his life still revolves around her, he expresses happiness then and now. Will is scared to share his potential with the world because he doesn't know what that might bring upon him and others. He's scared to see how society will view him. He enjoys his abilities but is fearful to put them into the world. Will's therapist whom is Robin Williams tries to read into Will in which Will begins to try and stab at him and this continues for multiple sessions and some sessions are just silent with no talking. Robin waits for Will to make the first move of speaking because he's not going to solve his problems for him. The most simple stories lead to the most valuable advice in which Will slowly starts to accept and they form a friendship. Eventually Will goes and gets the girl, he opens up and brings himself out there, he wants happiness and love. He started at the bottom and slowly climbs his way to the top.Overall, this movie is very well done. It's like a psych lesson. This movie is relate able to real life because there are many people out there just like Will and yet we turn a blind eye to them and they never get to express their true potential. The movies ends unknowingly just like real life, we never know where we will end up we can only imagine what will happen to us next and proceed to take those steps. It captures the human nature that we are too afraid to bring ourselves too. Highly interesting, charismatic, brilliant, rebelling film.

Good Will Hunting is the type of movie that you could go back and watch over and over again without it getting old. As a spectator, the cast did an amazing job making you feel like you were living in the movie in southie, particularly the scene where Robin Williams talks to Matt Damon while they sit on the bench in the park and is giving the young genius advice after they have a rocky first meeting. Robin Williams is talking to Matt Damon in a stern way telling him the way he goes about everything is that of a coward, but he makes it sound so calming. The way Ben Affleck tells his best friend he has to move on and do something with his life and even gets his friend a car despite his lack of wealth just to see his friend succeed is very moving to see that everyone is helping this one young man.
The ending is where I docked points from my review. Skylar is a key role in the movie because Will is clearly in love with her but he drives her away because of his defensive mechanism to not get too attached to people because of his rough abused past. She leaves and wants Will to join but he originally does not, but at the end he came to realize he had to go see about a girl, but the movie cuts off with Will driving on the highway to go to her but they didnt show him actually get there.

Review title: The ups and downs of Will
Review_body: This film had ups and downs. It was really though for commitment, this film was an emotional and inspirational in my opinion. This film delivered a hard, but became a positive message. The amount of commitment in this film is incredible and it shows a true friendship and loyalty. This film also showed a true friend, who helps you move on and encourages you to do better and stop doing the wrong, when a friend knows you can do better and that is capable to do better. I rate this a 10/10.In this film Will was always in trouble with the law. Will knew the potential he had, he always chose the streets instead of his future. He was scared to move on, he wanted to fit in with his friends instead of getting a good career. What I liked the most about Will is his loyalty to his friends. Will never wanted to move on because he only knew the street life and his friends. Will took is knowledge has a joke when he got in trouble with the law. I respected that from Will, it wasn't good to joke around about it. But the law didn't expect that from someone that got in trouble with the law all the time.Will found true love, a girl named Skylar. Will is scared to commit to a relationship, he thinks that everyone will leave him at the end of the day. This is something many people can relate too. Will went through therapy but he knew he didn't need it, he was taking therapy as a joke. He went through a lot to change and become better. Will was ready to change and take the job, but he left to see about a girl in california. The ending wasn't the best but it ended in him finding true love. This is why i give this a 10\10 I respect this film how Will changed for the better and went to California.

Good Will Hunting was a good movie, it shows that love can go a long way and in all different ways. Will Hunting double thinks but ends up going with his gut, i thought he should of went with the girl before she left. I see me in Will Hunting i double think but i go and get what i want, people judge Will even though they don't really know him people do that with me too. He has a different way of doing stuff and he's underestimated by others.
People don't think Will Hunting knows what he's talking about or doing because he's younger than them. But Will Hunting actually knows what he's talking about and doing, he's a smart guy. It doesn't better how young you are if you actually know what your talking about don't listen to what people got to say. Age doesn't matter if you know what your talking about. Will Hunting is a person who doesn't care what people say about him he would still go and do anything to help himself.
The only thing i didn't like was the cliffhanger in the end of the movie. I just wanted to see if he really made it to her or even to see if he married this girl. I rate this movie a 7, besides the ending i liked the whole movie. Will Hunting went with what his friends said they told him to go with his dreams without telling them when he's leaving and that's what he did. It was a great movie and i recommend this movie.

Good will hunting played by actor Matt Damon is a young man who works as a janitor staying with his "brother" actually best friend. One day while at the university he solves a puzzle left on a board by a math professor and he solved it. This starts showing how smart he is without actually even going to college. His best friend chuckie says "You know what the best part of my day is? For about 10 seconds from when I pull up to the curb to when I get there to your door, 'cause I think maybe I'll get up there and I'll knock on the door and you won't be there" he says this to Will because he just throws this talent this gift that's been gifted to him but just chooses to work construction or crappy jobs when he could be doing better. I've watched the movie on my own free time and with my english class. After have seeing the movie more than once you see it from a different perspective in many ways people could feel like Will. He's broke, working a crap job, barely getting by like many of us what is different between us and him is his intelligence the way he can fire up different parts of his brain and the way his brain analyzes the problem the complexity of it all. Will can look at any equation and his mind makes it possible to where it makes sense to him. Scientists say normal average beings use only 10% of their brains while people smarter and more fortunate like Steve hawking, or in this case Will hunting.
The writing is witty yet brilliant for a movie that's come out in 1997 it would seem by the way it was portrayed that it would've and could've been a movie that came out easily in 2007. Good Will Hunting was very hilarious at times, both Matt and Robin Williams preform wonderfully from both a comedic and theatrical prospective. Matt the actor playing Will says "You wasted $150,000 on an education you coulda got for $1.50 in late fees at the public library." which became one of his most famous quotes. Letting everyone know not everyone has to go to college to be smart or successful that it's okay not to have all the money in the world as long as you have yourself and you're mind.I would easily give the movie a 10 out of 10 stars and more if possible. The overall point of what makes the movie so great is the way it is built the way it's composed as one the way it all pieces together little by little to form such a master of work. I myself am not the type of person to rewatch things I can't stand knowing what happens so I don't like to rewatch things but a movie like this whether watched once or a hundred times its perspective it shows is just something you wouldn't wanna miss and that is why I rate this movie 10 out or 10.

Matt Damon portrays Will Hunting in the heartfelt movie Good Will Hunting (1997). Will (Matt Damon) works as a custodian at MIT. He secretly observes each class and the material that is taught. When the professor puts certain theorems on the blackboard that seem unsolvable, Will (Matt Damon) goes after hours to solve them. All the professors are baffled by the fact that he can solve the theorems. Although, problems start when Will (Matt Damon) gets into an altercation with a police officer and resists arrest. But to his luck, Professor Lambeau (Stellan Skarsgård) decides to pay his bail under two conditions. One, that he studies advanced mathematics with him. Two, that he receives therapy from another professor at the school.
Throughout the film, we see how Will faces many personal struggles. Such as, starting and ending a relationship with another woman, interviewing for different jobs, and dealing with issues from his early adolescence in his therapy sessions. This films shows the theme of happiness and how it is achieved despite personal struggles depicted by all of the character in some way, shape, or form.
Some strengths that we see in the film are the cast selections and the character development. The cast selection includes two very well known actors: Robin Williams and Matt Damon. Matt Damon is known for playing characters who often have a rough exterior but a good heart. Robin Williams is known for playing humorous characters who are very lovable but can be serious when the need be.
The acting talent is also present in this film. We see many fight scenes with Will (Matt Damon) which tells us a lot about his character but we also see him develop from that as well. We also see his girlfriend, Skylar (Minnie Driver) at the time in pain and sobbing because of Will (Matt Damon) which creates a sense of empathy for her character.
Another aspect of the film that is worth noting is the script and the language that it contains. The script contains a lot of curse words which can be intense for the viewers at times but it is necessary to characterize the era and the environment of the movie.
The music in this film was fitting for the events that were happening. There was often light music to set the scene in the beginning. Also there was calming music in between each scene which made for a smooth transition.
The lighting played an essential part of the film as well. The use of shadows and more obscure lighting was the most frequent in this film. A specific example would be when Will and the professor are in the interrogation room of the jail and since the scene is very intense, the lighting makes both of their facial features more piercing.
The setting of the movie shows Will's house that he lives in. We see that it is very run down and that he lives in a lower class neighborhood. This automatically shows where Will comes from and gives us empathy for him because of his humble beginnings. Then, it shows him when he arrives to the prestigious college of MIT and that is the exact opposite. We also see that he spends most of his time outside of work at the bar in the same neighborhood that he lives in.
The costume and makeup shows us the styles of the time period that this movie was filmed in. But most importantly, it shows a distinction between social classes. We see the difference between social classes when the professors and students at MIT are shown. We see when Will (Matt Damon) goes in for a job interview and he is not dressed to the standards of the employer.
Finally, there were two scenes that were extremely important to the film and they are very much worth analyzing. One, Will's (Matt Damon) very first therapy session with Sean (Robin Williams). We see that even though he is so intelligent and he seems invincible, he still has his troubled childhood and personal struggles that play a part into the way he is. As viewers, we hope to see how his character development plays out from there.
Another scene that is important is when Sean (Robin Williams) talks about how his wife has passed and how she made him so incredibly happy. We see the theme of happiness appear here and we see Will (Matt Damon) express a desire to obtain that same happiness.
Overall, this compelling film was heartfelt and each character was developed with a touch of humanity. We see how personal struggles and happiness fit hand and hand with each other. I truly recommend watching this film.

The fatherly figure performance that Robin Williams encapsulates is breathtaking; with a trusting warmth and glow to his character. The working class lifestyle Will lives by is conflicted by his vast knowledge and abilities which he must address to progress with his life. Will being someone of weak character suffers from opening up to new people in his life and would rather confide to the loyalty he has already established with his life long friend - Will is portrayed a relatable character, one who fears revealing his true emotions. The long and awkward camera zooms is what sells the true tormented emotions the characters are feeling, it allows Damon to show the true extent of his acting abilities and completely smashes it.
All time favourite, watching Matt Damon and Ben Affleck as young actors is truly mesmerizing in this one!
One of the best movies ever! i wish have the advanced brain as leo over this movie!
This movie was so real and honest. It's one that I can always go back and rewatch. Robin Williams makes the movie though, truly. The park bench scene is so good.

Good Will Hunting is an excellent movie. The movie touches upon many aspects of human life. It shows fear, friendship, love, potential, pride, and sorrow along with many other aspects of human life. Good Will Hunting shows real human struggles, and real human triumphs. It has a great deal of genuine humanity for a film.
Good Will Hunting follows a young troubled genius named Will (Matt Damon)who lives in Boston. As the movie starts Will is working as a janitor at MIT. One of the Math professors at MIT writes an incredibly challenging problem on a chalkboard in a hallway and challenges students to solve it. Will solves it after hours and the Professor sees him but Will runs away. Will then hangs out with some friends and gets in a fight. He is going to be sent to jail when the Professor tracks him down, and gives him two conditions to be let out of jail: meet with him for math once a week, and meet with a therapist once a week. Will accepts and this sets the stage for the whole movie. His therapist Sean Maguire (Robin Williams) and him continue to meet. Will is reluctant at first but he starts to trust Sean. Will also gets a girlfriend and starts to develop genuine feelings for her.
The movie has excellent characters and dialogue. When two characters talk on screen it feels like a real conversation. The way characters seem so comfortable with each other reminds me of the Oceans movies. The characters have realistic and consistent motives for their actions. The film also uses lots of humor, Will and his friends make fun of each other and the joking feels natural. Some scenes don't advance the plot but it doesn't feel like a waste because watching these characters just interact is captivating. There really aren't any major drawbacks of this movie for me. But it does use a lot of time to set the plot up. The story starts of fairly generic as well. When the movies plot gets going though and the climax is approaching I found myself genuinely glued to the screen. The movie's directing and soundtrack aren't groundbreaking, but they don't need to be for this film and they do their jobs well enough. The actors all do phenomenal jobs. This movie is some of the best acting I've seen from Matt Damon and Robin Williams.
The main strength of this movie is its humanity. It shows many challenges that real people face and it shows these challenges in a real way. The movie shows people dealing with the fear of the unknown and fear of commitment through the main character Will. Will also struggles letting people in and letting people know about his issues. The main struggles at the center of this movie are inherent struggles that come along with being human. Will may be incredibly genius but he's still easy to relate to. The way Will and his friends interact with each other is incredibly natural. Them arguing and joking in the car is incredibly fun to watch. But the best scene that showcases humanity in this movie when Will and Sean are sitting outside on a bench. Will starts cracking some jokes at Sean's expense but then Sean starts talking. Sean tells Will all the things he hasn't experienced yet in life, but the way Sean is doing it is outlining his own life. He's telling Will about the struggles that he's been through. The struggles that come with living a real life. Because the main lesson Sean wants will to learn is to not be afraid to live a real life and put himself out there. The acting in this scene by Robin Williams is immaculate. I've never seen anything done by him that tops this monologue. A Dead Poets Society rivals it.The writing in this scene is just beautiful.
Good Will Hunting is one of the few movies I've seen were the characters seem genuinely real and the movie is still captivating. It has that balance between cinematic moments and real human moments. I was sad when this movie ended because I didn't want to stop watching. I wanted to see more of these characters. The movie was centered around human struggles and human triumphs. This movie is a definite human triumph.
I really enjoyed this movie. From the actors performances to the way it's directed truly captivating
I saw this film on the day I woke up crying because of some nightmares and I have to say it had the ability to make my day better.
The most amazing movie I've ever seen, so touched i love it so much

You gotta like this if you like meaningful movies.The plot is kind of very "Hollywoddish" come to think about it. "the mathematical genius + redneck from Boston gets fixed by the ultra cool looks like a failure but actually a winner shrink". now the beauty of the movie is that they acted and directed this plot out in a very believable way. I mean this plot and storyline could have easily been killed if it was done by some other people. Hats off to the cast, the director, and the writers(who r also part of the cast).Matt Damone and Robin williams acted "Real". THats a very important factor . And the girl, well if she ain't British then she sure can act! The chemistry was awesome between matt damone and the girl(sorry don know her name).Only reason, the only reason why I did'nt give the movie a 10 was that I felt that the storytelling lacked direction at times. everything else was just as close to perfection as it can be. The ending made me say "wow".Don't see this movie if you are expecting a typical Hollywood "weeeee look what we have found. A genius from the gutters. Well show you the cool transformations in his life". See this for some amazing acting (esp by matt damone and robin williams), some truly awesome dialogs and a very cool ending.

This movie was so important in so many ways and it touched me deep inside. It was not overrated at all- hello it came out in the year of Titanic. I think it deserved Best Picture. It also launched the careers of Ben Affleck and Matt Damon. (I love both- but Ben is awesome). They are both very talented and deserved all the credit they got. And Robin Williams ends up winning an Oscar with one of his only serious roles. How ironic? He gave the best performance of his career. Although Ben and Matt wrote it and everything- Robin just stole the picture. It wouldn't have been the same without his portrayal of Sean Maguire.This was the feel-good movie of the year and just such a great story. You all should agree.

Review title: A timeless movie that I can watch over and over again
Review_body: This is one of those movies that whenever I see it on the guide I have to watch it. Robin Williams and Matt Damon are magic together on the screen and it makes me wish that they had collaborated on more films. Good Will Hunting has stood the test of time and I truly believe this movie is a MUST SEE for everyone.

Review title: "Good Will Hunting" is a film that pulls at the heartstrings of the viewers
Review_body:
